content:
CMJ   
llyanassa laboratory          
Examine the capsule collection for a capsule of suitable stage (the capsules have
been collected by removing them from the agquarium wall with a razor blade.). lf a
capsule is suitable, roll the capsule around on a paper towel with a needle to free it
of adherent jelly, debris and water. Transfer it to sterile sea water in a small petri
dish. A steel dissecting needle and a pair of fine scissors or a single edge razor blade
will be needed for opening the capsule. Using the low power of the dissecting microscope,
hold one end of the capsule against the dish with the needle and remove the other end
with the scissors or razor blade. The eggs will be held in the capsule by The
jelly is soluble in sea water and will ultimately dissolve. The capsule should be allowed
to sit for l0-15 minutes to allow the jelly to partially dissolve; the eggs can then be
expelled from the capsule by gently pressing it with a steel needle. Transfer the
liberated eggs with a mouth pipette to a clean dish with sterile sea water.
Normal Development: The fertilized uncleaved Tlyanassa egg is about l65 pm in diameter.
lt is fertilized prior to laying. Shortly after the capsule is laid the first polar body
is given off. As it is forming,the first polar lobe appears. This lobe is inconspicuous;
the only indication of its presence is a slight elongation along the animal-vegetal axis of
the egg, which gives the egg a top-like appearance. About 30 minutes (at 24 C.) after
first polar lobe formation, second polar body formation takes place. A second polar lobe
begins to develop about 20 minutes prior to second polar body formation and continues to
enlarge for some time after the second polar body is formed. The second polar lobe is
very broad and is more constricted from the rest of the cytoplasm than the first polar
lobe. The third polar lobe begins to develop about 80 minutes after the second polar body.
lt takes about 50 minutes from the beginning of third polar lobe formation to the trefoil
stage when the polar lobe is maximagly constricted. This stage coincides with the end of
the first cleavage. This stage lasts for several minutes; then a short yolk-free stalk
can be seen connecting the lobe to one of the blastomeres. The stalk broadens as the
contents of the lobe flow into one blastomere. The resulting blastomeres are unequal in
size. The smaller blastomere is denominated AB, while the larger blastomere, CD}contains
the contents of the polar lobe. The fourth and final polar lobe appears in the vegetal
region of the CD cell as it undergoes its next division. The fourth polar lobe is the
same size as the third polar lobe. After the second cleavage is completed there are three
small cells: and C, and a large cell, D, which contains the lobe substance.
The Ilyanassa embryo develops into a veligger larva. The veliger larva has a pigmented
oesophagus, stomach, and intestine. The velum bears large cilia and has a pigmented rim.
Shell, operculum, foot, eyes, otocyst and heart are easily seen by 5-6 days of development
(see figure)
Experiments: llyanassa embryos that are raised outside of the shell are subject to
bacterial infections. This leads to embryonic death. In order to avoid infection it is
necessary to transfer embryos through several changes of sterile sea water to dilute out
the bacteria before manipulating them.
l) Removal of the polar lobe: To remove the polar lobe at the trefoil stage, wait
until the lobe is connected by only a slender thread of cytoplasm and is itself almost
sperical. Then press across the lobe connection as indicated in the diagrams.MOr;a1ity is
lower if the glass knife does not cut
5557 through the lobqbonnections immediately.
Instead press across the connection, then
release the pressure and repeat after a half
minute or so. By passing from egg to egg
a number may be thus conditioned. Then go
- ft *back over the series and cut the lobe off
with a firm stroke. Polar lobe removals
